facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 471 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 471 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 9, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1627 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 9- 1960 of the Punjab High. Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1627 of 1960.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Mudholkar, J. The short point which falls to be companysidered in this appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab dismissing the appellants appeal in limine is whether the suit for possession instituted by the plaintiff-respondent No. 1 is within time.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed the appellant's appeal in limine.

anchor.surface_text: ...companysidered in this appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab dismissing the appellants appeal in limine is whether the suit for possession...

facts.text: There are ten respondents to the appeal, out of whom only two, the plaintiff-respondent No. 1 Amardas and respondent No. 11 Union of India are represented.

anchor.surface_text: There are ten respondents to the appeal out of whom only two, the plaintiff-respondent No. 1 Amardas and respondent No. 11 Union of India are represented. While the appeal is companytested by the first respondent it is supported by the Union of India.

facts.text: The facts which are not disputed before us are briefly these.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number disputed before us are briefly these The appellant has a share of 1221/143 1/2 in the land in suit.

facts.text: The appellant has a share of 1221/143 1/2 in the land in suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has a share of 1221/143 1/2 in the land in suit. The occupancy tenant of this land is Akhara Nirbansar of Sultanwind Gate, Amritsar.

facts.text: The occupancy tenant of this land is Akhara Nirbansar of Sultanwind Gate, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The occupancy tenant of this land is Akhara Nirbansar of Sultanwind Gate, Amritsar. The second respondent Ram Saran Das was Mahant of this Akhara till the year 1950 when he was removed by virtue of an order made by a civil companyrt...

facts.text: The second respondent Ram Saran Das was Mahant of this Akhara till the year 1950 when he was removed by virtue of an order made by a civil court in a suit under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, confirmed in appeal on September 11, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent Ram Saran Das was Mahant of this Akhara till the year 1950 when he was removed by virtue of an order made by a civil companyrt in a suit under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, companyfirmed in appeal on September 11, 1950.

facts.text: On December 29, 1953 respondent No. 1 was appointed as Mahant in place of respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1953 respondent No. 1 was appointed as Mahant in place of respondent No. 2.

facts.text: On September 15, 1939 the appellant instituted a suit in a revenue court under ss. 38 and 39 of the Punjab Tenancy Act for possession of 141 kanals 8 marlas of land.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1939 the appellant instituted a suit in a revenue companyrt under ss. 38 and 39 of the Punjab Tenancy Act  hereafter referred to as the Act  for possession of 141 kanals 8 marlas of land on the ground that he had granted a sub-lease thereof...

facts.text: The Revenue Court held that out of the land sub-leased by respondent No. 2 only a certain portion was dug up by the sub-lessee and, therefore, the ejectment of the second respondent was confined to that area of land which had been dug up. The date of the ejectment decree was June 3, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Court held that out of the land sub-leased by respondent No. 2 only a certain portion was dug up by the sub-lessee and, therefore, the ejectment of the second respondent was companyfined to that area of land which had been dug up. The date of the ejectment decree was June 3, 1940.

facts.text: The second respondent preferred an appeal before the Collector from that decree which was dismissed on October 19, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent preferred an appeal before the Collector from that decree which was dismissed on October 19, 1940. Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land from which the second respondent was ordered to be ejected.

facts.text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land from which the second respondent was ordered to be ejected.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land from which the second respondent was ordered to be ejected.

facts.text: The Assistant Collector who tried the suit granted a decree to the appellant in respect of the entire land which was left with the second respondent after he was dispossessed from a part of the land leased to him under the earlier decree.

anchor.surface_text: The lessee of the second respondent, however, companytinued to dig up the rest of the land and, therefore, the appellant instituted a second suit for the ejectment of the second respondent therefrom. The Assistant Collector who tried the suit granted a decree...

facts.text: In appeal, however, the Collector modified the order of ejectment by leaving out of the land 29 kanals and 14 marlas. This order was made on May 31, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, however, the Collector modified the order of ejectment by leaving out of the land 29 kanals and 14 marlas. This order was made on May 31, 1943.

facts.text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land with respect to which the Collector had confirmed the order of ejectment in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land with respect to which the Collector had companyfirmed the order of ejectment in the appeal.

facts.text: On March, 18, 1957 the first respondent instituted a suit against the appellant and the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On March, 18, 1957 the first respondent instituted a suit against the appellant and the second respondent.

facts.text: The suit was decreed by the trial court and its decision was upheld in appeal by the second Additional District Judge, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the trial companyrt and its decision was unheld in appeal by the second Additional District Judge, Amritsar.

facts.text: The appellants second appeal was dismissed in limine by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants second appeal was dismissed in limine by the High Court.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 claimed Akhara Nirbansar was not bound by the actions of Mahant Ram Saran Das, which were tantamount to alienation of the land neither for legal necessity nor for the benefit of the estate.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondent No. 1 Akhara Nirbansar was number bound by the actions of Mahant Ram Saran Das, the second respondent, which were tantamount to alienation of the land which, according to him, were neither for legal necessity number for the benefit of the estate.

facts.text: Appellant contested that the land in question was never attached to the Akhara but that Mahant Ram Saran Das was its occupancy tenant and that occupancy rights were extinguished by the orders of the revenue courts.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit on two main grounds. The first was that the land in question was never attached to the Akhara but that Mahant Ram Saran Das, the second respondent, was its occupancy tenant...

facts.text: Appellant was in continuous possession of the land in suit as owner for more than 12 years preceding the suit openly and to the exclusion of the second respondent and respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The second point was that as the appellant was in companytinuous possession of the land in suit as owner in his own right for more than 12 years preceding the suit openly and to the exclusion of the second respondent and respondent No. 1 the suit was barred by time.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 in his replication has not disputed the fact that the appellant was in possession for more than 12 years before the institution of the suit.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the learned Solicitor General, respondent No. 1 in his replication has number disputed the fact that the appellant was in possession for more than 12 years before the institution of the suit...

facts.text: Upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.

holdings.text: upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eviction decrees under Punjab Tenancy Act ss. 38-39 resulted in landlord obtaining full possession, causing merger of inferior occupancy right into superior ownership right.

holdings.text: the actual physical possession of the land having been continuously with the appellant to the exclusion of the occupancy tenant, whether it was respondent No. 1 or the Akhara itself, for a period more than 12 years before the institution of the suit that right was extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that it is clear that the actual physical possession of the land having been continuously with the appellant to the exclusion of the occupancy tenant, whether it was respondent No. 1 or the Akhara itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed continuous exclusive possession as owner for over 12 years before suit extinguishes any prior occupancy or trust rights under limitation principles.

holdings.text: what happened in this case was the forfeiture of the occupancy tenancy by the appellant as landlord. In no sense can this be regarded as, or even likened to alienation, which is a voluntary act of the alienor in favour of the alienee.

anchor.surface_text: The simple answer to this contention is that what happened in this case was the forfeiture of the occupancy tenancy by the appellant as landlord. In no sense can this be regarded as, or even likened to alienation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ejectment for breach under ss. 38-39 Punjab Tenancy Act is involuntary forfeiture by landlord, not voluntary alienation requiring legal necessity.

holdings.text: it cannot be said in the case before us that at any point of time there was no person who was competent to institute a suit on behalf of the Akhara. Respondent No. 2 was still the Mahant and could well have instituted a suit on behalf of the Akhara if in fact there was any cause of action for such a suit.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming these observations are sound, it cannot be said in the case before us that at any point of time there was no person who was competent to institute a suit on behalf of the Akhara. Respondent No. 2 was still the Mahant and could well have instituted a suit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Existing Mahant remained competent to sue on behalf of Akhara despite removal proceedings; receiver also competent.

holdings.text: a Mahant of an Akhara represents the Akhara and has both the right to institute a suit on its behalf as also the duty to defend one brought against it.

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that a Mahant of an Akhara represents the Akhara and has both the right to institute a suit on its behalf as also the duty to defend one brought against it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mahant acts as representative with authority to sue or defend on institution's behalf, per Hindu law principles.

holdings.text: in the case of an execution sale of debutter property it is not the date of death of the incumbent of the Mutt but the date of effective possession as a result of the sale from which the commencement of the adverse possession of the purchaser is to be computed for the purposes of art. 144 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out that in the case of an execution sale of debutter property it is not the date of death of the incumbent of the Mutt but the date of effective possession as a result of the sale from which the commencement

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Privy Council precedents (Sudarsan Das, Subbaiya), limitation under Art. 144 runs from effective dispossession, not incumbent's death/removal.

holdings.text: the tenants occupancy rights were extinguished by the decrees passed in the ejectment suits

anchor.surface_text: the original occupancy tenant of the land was the second respondent and not the Akhara and also contended that whether it was one or the other made no difference. For, the tenants occupancy rights were extinguished by the decrees passed in the ejectment suits

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue court ejectment decrees under PTA ss.38-39 finally extinguished tenancy rights of second respondent (held to be original tenant).

holdings.text: decrees made in them would bind the respondent No. 1 as he is successor in office of respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Thus if respondent No. 2 could be said to have represented the Akhara in the two earlier suits, decrees made in them would bind the respondent No. 1 as he is successor in office of respondent No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Successor Mahant bound by decrees against predecessor who represented the Akhara.

precedents.citation: Dwijendra Narain Roy v. Joges Chandra De 1

anchor.surface_text: In support of the companytention he has placed reliance upon the decision in Dwijendra Narain Roy v. Joges Chandra De 1 . In particular learned companynsel has relied upon the following observations of Mookerjee J., who delivered the judgment of the Court. They are The substance of the matter is that time runs when the cause of action accrues, and a cause of action accrues, when there is in existence a person who can sue and another who can be sued The cause of action arises when and only when the aggrieved party has the right to apply to the proper tribunals for relief.

precedents.case_name: Dwijendra Narain Roy v. Joges Chandra De
precedents.cited_proposition: time runs when the cause of action accrues, and a cause of action accrues when there is in existence a person who can sue and another who can be sued; the cause of action arises when the aggrieved party has the right to apply to the proper tribunals for relief; statute of limitation does not run until there is a right of action
precedents.cited_holding: The substance of the matter is that time runs when the cause of action accrues, and a cause of action accrues, when there is in existence a person who can sue and another who can be sued The cause of action arises when and only when the aggrieved party has the right to apply to the proper tribunals for relief. The statute of limitation does number attach to a claim for which there is as yet numberright of action and does number run against a right for which there is numbercorresponding remedy or for which judgment cannot be obtained. Consequently the true test to determine when a cause of action has accrued is to ascertain the time when plaintiff companyld first have maintained his action to a successful result.

precedents.citation: F. Lakshmi Reddy v. L. Lakshmi Reddy 2

anchor.surface_text: He further brought to our numberice that these observations have received the approval of this Court in F. Lakshmi Reddy v. L. Lakshmi Reddy 2 , at p. 206. In the case which came up before this Court the facts which are set out in the head numbere were as follows V died an infant in 1927 and H, an agnatic relation filed a suit for the recovery of the properties belonging to V which were in the possession of third parties, on the ground that he was the sole nearest male magnate entitled to all the properties.

precedents.case_name: F. Lakshmi Reddy v. L. Lakshmi Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: approval of observations on when cause of action accrues for limitation purposes

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out that in the case of an execution sale of debutter property it is number the date of death of the incumbent of the Mutt but the date of effective possession as a result of the sale from which the companymencement of the adverse possession of the purchaser is to be companyputed for the purposes of art. 144 of the Limitation Act. This is in fact what the Privy Council has laid down in Sudarsan Das v. Ram Kirpal 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: in the case of an execution sale of debutter property it is not the date of death of the incumbent but the date of effective possession as a result of the sale from which the commencement of adverse possession is computed for limitation purposes

anchor.surface_text: A similar view has been taken by the Privy Council in Subbaiya v. Mustapha 2 . What has been said in this case would also apply to a case such as the present. Thus if respondent No. 2 companyld be said to have represented the Akhara in the two earlier suits, decrees made in them would bind the respondent No. 1 as he is successor in office of respondent No.

precedents.cited_proposition: similar view to commencement of adverse possession not from death of incumbent but effective possession

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.
